1. Introduction 
At the last Intemational Vacuum Electron Sources Conference, held in Saratov, Russia, the current authors 
presented a paper reporting on preliminary findings from an investigation into the interfacial layer that forms in 
the oxide cathode over accelerated cathode life (Jenkins et irl. 2003). It was reported that studies were being 
conducted to investigate key issues that could bring about improvement in performance to the oxide cathode, in 
order for the oxide cathode to remain a competitive display technology. One of the key issues identified was the 
need for characterisation of the interface layer that forms during the operation of an oxide cathode. Although 
this subject has been investigated extensively before (Rooksby 1940) (Rooksby 1947) (Eisenstein 1949) 
(Wright 1947), ambiguity remains conceming both the nature and the effect of the interfacial layer on the 
performance of the oxide cathode. There is firm evidence to indicate that this interfacial layer blocks the 
'activating' elements which are necessary for the reduction of the bdrium oxide in the emissive layer to give the 
free barium that lowers the work function. This blocking effect, therefore, reduces the performance of the 
cathode. In this study the interfacial layer was characterised using a number of analytical techniques in order to 
obtain a comprehensive understanding of the geometry and chemistry of this layer. The techniques that have 
been used are scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), secondary ion mass 
spectroscopy (SIMS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). 
2. Experimental 
Dummy tube electron gun assemblies were constructed and operated under simulated accelerated lifetime 
testing for 0 h, 1000 h and 2000 h. A range of sample preparation methods was used during this study for 
emissive oxide layer removal. The first entailed stripping the oxide coating away from the nickel substrate with 
tape (sometimes repetitively) until the oxide coating was removed from a sizeable amount of the cathode area, 
thus exposing the underlying interface between the nickel and oxide coating. Another method was cross 
sectioning at the interface. This was achieved in two different ways. The first was producing a tapered cross 
section by mounting the cathode onto a 10" aluminium wedge, setting in resin and polishing to a 3pm finish 
followed by a final polish with a silica oxide particle suspension. The final type of cross sections were obtained 
by init/ally stripping the coating, followed by etching away material from both sides of an area of interest with a 
focused ion beam (W). Specimens were investigated with TEM. S E E D X  images and spectra were acquired 
at 15 keV on a Jeol 8600 Super probe using an Oxford Instruments INCA EDX detector. AES spectra were 
collected using a VG Microlab Mk 11, using a York field emission gun set at 15 keV with a specimen current of 
12 nA. The spherical analyser was operated at CRR 4. A liquid gallium source was used when etching with the 
W. It was operated with a beam energy of 30keV and 12nA. SIMS depth profiles and images were collected 
using pulsed 25 .keV gold ions (0.03 PA) for the analysis and 1 keV oxygen ions were used to etch into the 
sample bulk during profiling. TEM images, electron diffraction pattems and EDX spectra were obtained using a 
Philips CM200 TEM operating at 200 keV.

4. Conclusions 
A range of surface and analytical techniques were used to investigate the intekctions taking place at the oxide 
cathode interface during operation. h g e  cracks were found to form in the bulk alloy, these regions being rich 
in Ba, Mg, AI and 0. It seemed probable that intemal oxidation of the nickel waS taking place and these cracks 
form an internal surface at ,which the barium oxide was being reduced by the Mg and Al activators. In addition, 
a thin layer reaction product containing Ba, Sr, 0 and AI formed at the nickel alloy I nickel oxide.interface. 
There was a direct correlation between the thickness of the interfacial nickel oxide and operational time. The 
observations support the view that the majority of cracks formed during activation and ageing. Whilst these 
cracks continued to grow during accelerated lifetime testing, the number of cracks 
Rem ained constant. The fact that the skin layer only contained the Al activator and the cracks contain both Mg 
and AI activators, coupled with the higher Mg diffusion coefficient suggested AI was particularly associated 
with cathode life performance with Mg being most important in the earliest stages of cathode operation.
